name: Green Tree Python
description: It is a slender python with a typically triangular head and distinct neck. As an adult, it has a bright green coloration. A row of white or yellowish scales runs along its back, forming a broken or continuous line. The belly is yellow or whitish.
image_alt: Green Tree Python, photo: Vladimír Motyčka, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 1.5–2 m, with the tail about 20%; weight 1–1.5 kg
reproduction: Females lay 15–20 eggs; incubation averages 3.5 months
attractions: The green tree python is tied to tree canopies. It hunts birds and other vertebrates there, and females lay eggs, stuck together, in hollows or forks. Hatchlings are yellow to brick-red. It often rests on a branch with its head coiled in the middle loop of its body.
breeding: We have kept green tree pythons since 1990, though one specimen appeared at the zoo as early as 1982.
